questions.text: Edmond Locard is most known for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Edmond Locard is most famously known for his Theory of Exchange, often referred to as Locard's Exchange Principle.

  • Edmond Locard, a pioneering French criminologist, is widely regarded as the father of modern forensic science.
  • Locard's Exchange Principle: The central tenet of forensic science, stating that "every contact leaves a trace." This highlights the inevitability of material transfer during any interaction.
  • Significance: This principle guides the collection and analysis of all forms of trace evidence (e.g., fibres, hair, soil, glass fragments) at a crime scene.
  • Poroscopy: Locard also developed poroscopy, a specialised technique for studying fingerprint pores for individual identification, though it is less widely recognised than his Exchange Principle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Study of fingerprints (Choice A): Sir Edward Richard Henry is widely recognised for developing the first systematic classification system of fingerprints (Henry Classification System) used globally.

Stature estimation (Choice C): The notable work in stature estimation from long bones is attributed to Rollet (1888), who published extensive tables for this purpose.

Forensic ballistics (Choice D): The initial success in forensic ballistics is generally credited to Henry Goddard in 1835, who famously matched a bullet to a specific mould.

Key Takeaways:

  • Edmond Locard is predominantly recognized for his "Theory of Exchange" / "Locard's Exchange Principle."

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal term corpus delicti?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The legal term corpus delicti translates to "the body of offence."

  • Corpus Delicti: The essential facts proving that a crime has been committed. It's distinct from proving who committed the crime.
  • Two main components:
    1. Proof of a specific loss or injury (e.g., a dead body in homicide, stolen goods in larceny).
    2. Proof that this loss or injury was caused by the criminal agency (not natural causes, accident, or suicide).

Explanation of Other Options:

Medico-legal autopsy (Choice A): This is a post-mortem examination conducted for legal purposes, often to establish cause, manner, and time of death, which contributes to establishing corpus delicti but is not the definition itself.

Criminal negligence (Choice C): This refers to a type of mental state or conduct where a person acts with a reckless disregard for the safety of others, leading to harm. It's a component of some crimes, but not the definition of corpus delicti.

Exhumation (Choice D): This is the act of digging up a buried body. It may be performed as part of a medico-legal investigation to re-examine a body, potentially aiding in establishing corpus delicti, but it is not the definition of the term.

Key Takeaways:

  • Corpus delicti is the "body of offence," establishing that a crime has occurred due to criminal action.

questions.text: When are the fingerprint patterns determined?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fingerprint patterns are definitively determined by the 4th month of gestation (approximately 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life) and remain fixed and unique for an individual throughout their entire life.

  • Formation of Fingerprints: Formed by papillary or epidermal ridges on the fingertips, palms, and soles.
  • Timing of Determination: Patterns begin to appear around 12-16 weeks (4th month) of intrauterine life.
  • Completion of Formation: The intricate ridge patterns are generally completed by 24 weeks of gestation.
  • Permanence: Once formed, fingerprint patterns are permanent and unchangeable throughout life, even with superficial injuries. Only deep injuries that destroy the dermis can alter them.
  • Uniqueness: Each individual's fingerprints are unique, forming the basis for their use in forensic identification.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fingerprint patterns are determined early in fetal development, specifically by the 4th month of gestation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the fundamental fingerprint patterns, Loops are consistently the most common (60-70%). A loop pattern is characterized by ridges that enter from one side of the impression, recurve, and then exit on the same side.

  • Fingerprint Classification: Fingerprint patterns are broadly categorized into three main types: Loops, Whorls, and Arches. Composite patterns are variations or combinations of these.
  • Relative Frequencies (Approximate):
    • Loops: 60-70% (most common)
    • Whorls: 25-35% (second most common) (Choice B)
    • Arches: 5% (least common) (Choice C &D)
  • Types of Arches: Arches are further subdivided into Plain Arches and Tented Arches. Both are relatively rare compared to loops and whorls.

Key Takeaways:

  • Loops are the most prevalent fingerprint pattern

questions.text: While investigating a case of homicide, the forensic team finds that the fingerprints left behind have no delta formation. Which fingerprint pattern is described here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Plain arches have no delta. (triangular ridge divergence)
  • Classification of fingerprints into different patterns is based on the delta and core formation.
    • Delta is a triangular arrangement formed where three separate ridge line flows come together.
    • The core is the centremost portion of a ridge flow pattern.
  • Composite patterns are combinations of loops, whorls, or arches and may have varying numbers of deltas depending on the specific pattern (e.g., central pocket loop, double loop). However, they are not characterized by the absence of deltas, unlike plain arches.

Explanation of other options:

Tented arches (Choice A) have one delta, resembling a tent-like structure.

Whorls (Choice B) have two deltas, forming circular or spiral patterns.

Loops (Choice D) have one delta, with ridges entering and exiting from the same side.

Key Takeaways:

Mnemonic: LAW 102

  • L for Loop → has 1 delta
  • A for Arch → has 0 deltas
  • W for Whorl → has 2 deltas

Explanation:

Chance fingerprints, also known as latent fingerprints, are invisible or barely visible impressions left unintentionally on smooth surfaces due to natural secretions (e.g., sweat, oils). They require development techniques (e.g., dusting, fuming) for visualization.

Explanation of other options:

Patent fingerprints (Choice C): Visible fingerprints formed by fingers stained with substances like blood, ink, or paint.

Plastic fingerprints (Choice D): Impressions left in soft, pliable materials like soap, wax, or mud.

Visible fingerprints (Choice B): Synonymous with patent fingerprints, not chance fingerprints.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quetelet's rule: Every nature-made object shows infinite variations of forms, and in the world's, crime records no two identical fingerprint patterns have been reported.
  • Hence, it is unique to every individual.
  • Fingerprint patterns differ in identical twins due to epigenetic influences and random variations in fetal ridge development, despite identical DNA.
  • Blood group, DNA fingerprinting and iris color are the same in identical twins

choices.text: Sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges
Fissures and grooves on lip print

questions.text: While reading a forensic report, you notice that the identification of the suspect was done through edgeoscopy. What does this method evaluate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Edgeoscopy is a method of identification through the examination of the unique details and characteristics found along the edges of individual fingerprint ridges.

Methods of identification using different prints:

  • Dactylography - Evaluation of fingerprints
  • Poroscopy - Evaluation of sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges
  • Cheiloscopy - Evaluation of lip prints
  • Podography - Evaluation of footprints
  • Rugoscopy - Evaluation of palatal rugae
  • Ridgeology - Evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints

questions.text:
A person of interest in a homicide case is on the run from the police. He wishes to remove the tattoo on his left arm which is very prominent. Which of the following methods may be used for the same?
1. Surgical excision
2. Scarification with sandpaper
3. Caustic soda
4. Rubbing with isopropyl alcohol
5. Electrolysis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methods for deliberate tattoo removal include:

  1. Surgical methods: (Statement 1)
    • Complete excision and skin grafting
    • Production of burn using red hot iron
    • Scarification with sandpaper (Statement 2)
    • Carbon dioxide snow
  2. Electrolysis (Statement 5)
  3. Caustic substances remove pigment by producing an inflammatory reaction and a superficial scar, e.g., a mixture of papain in glycerine, zinc chloride and tannic acid. (Statement 3)
  4. LASER beam: By exposure to laser beams, the particles of the dye get vapourised and expelled from the tissues in gaseous form
  5. Confluent smallpox and sometimes chronic eczema in children can obliterate tattoo marks

Explanation of other options:

Rubbing with isopropyl alcohol (Statement 4): Isopropyl alcohol is not effective for tattoo removal, as it does not affect the pigment embedded in the dermis.

questions.text: In tattoos, which of the following colours is least likely to fade over time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Black areas in a tattoo are the least likely to fade over the
  • This is because the black pigment (carbon particles) is more resistant than the other pigments to transportation by the lymphatic system.
  • Thus, they tend to persist in the skin.
  • Colours such as blue, green, or red are scavenged by tissue cells and leached into the lymphatic system after several years or decades.
  • Light colours such as white, pink, and blue fade faster.

choices.text: Rubbing the part and examining with a magnifying lens

questions.text: An unidentified dead body is brought to you for autopsy. You notice a faded tattoo mark on the left arm of the body. All of the following methods would be used to visualize the same except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ink blotting is notused to visualize tattoos.
  • A faded tattoo mark can be visualized by:
    • Ultraviolet light
    • Infrared photography
    • Rubbing the part and examining it with a magnifying lens

questions.text: A deceased male was brought to the morgue for a post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lymph nodesshould be examined in this case.
  • Some amount of material or dyeused for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Hence cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined.
  • Migration of tattoo pigment particles from the dermis to lymph nodes can mimic other disease processes at surgery and on imaging.
  • The gross black appearance of a sentinel lymph node is highly suggestive of metastatic disease when lymph node dissection is performed for melanoma treatment.

choices.text: Cortex is four to ten times as broad as the medulla

questions.text: What is true regarding human hair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In human hair, the cortex is typically 4-10 times broader than the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following can be determined using the cephalic index?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Race can be determined using the cephalic index.

questions.text: The forensic department received the postmortem remains of a partly decayed body, which was recovered from the outskirts near an international airport. They notice that an oval cross-section of hair is seen on the scalp. What would have been the likely race of the person?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Caucasoids have light-colored, reddish or golden hair. They are curly or wavy and the cross section is
  • Negroids have dark-colored They are woolly and arranged in tight spirals, and the cross-section is kidney-shaped.
  • Mongoloids have dark-coloured They are straight, and the cross-section is round.

choices.text: Absence of the upper third molar

questions.text: Human skeletal remains were found in an abandoned basement in Wuhan. Which of the following would indicate that the victim was a Caucasian?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carabelli cusps are most commonly seen only in Caucasian races and rare in the other major racial groups.
  • These are small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars.

Features of Mongoloid dentition include:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - The posterior surfaces of these teeth have a central depression. (Option C)
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Taurodontism (Bull-tooth) - The pulp cavity of the molars is wide and deep. (Option A)
  • Frequent absence of upper third molar (Option D)
  • Long pointed canines

choices.text: 2 Barr bodies are seen in a person with 47XXY genetic makeup
Barr body may be seen in a genetic male
Davidson's body is seen in the female neutrophil nucleus
A common site for sex chromatin sampling in dead is tooth pulp

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sex chromatin is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The number of Barr bodies is determined by the formula n-1, where n is the number of X chromosomes. In a 47XXY individual (Klinefelter syndrome), there are 2 X chromosomes, so 2-1= 1 Barr body.

  • Sex chromatin:It is a small planoconvex mass [about one micron in diameter lying near the nuclear membrane (Barr body) demonstrated by Dixon and Tarr]. It represents the inactivated X chromosome.
  • In the buccal smear, the percentage of nuclei containing chromatin body ranges from zero to four in males and 20 to 80 in females.
  • In females, neutrophil leucocytes contain a small nuclear attachment of drumstick form (Davidson body) in about 3% of cells. This is absent in males. (Option C)
  • The number of Barr bodies in someone with 47XXY genetic makeup is 1, not 2. (Option B)
  • The number of Barr bodies is given by the formula n-1, where n is the number of X chromosomes.
  • Tooth pulp is a common site for sex chromatin sampling in deceased individuals. (Option D)
  • Barr body is a small plano-convex mass, lying near the nuclear membrane.

questions.text:
Which of the following indices are used to determine the sex of an individual?
1. Intermembral index
2. Sternal index
3. Corporo Basal sacral index
4. Ischiopubic index
5. Cephalic index
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sternal index, corporobasal sacral index, and ischiopubic index are used to determine the sex of the individual.

The intermembral index and cephalic index help determine the race of the individual.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining the pelvic bone and lower vertebrae of an unknown individual, to determine the sex. Which of the following is regarded as the best source of information for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pubisof the pelvic bone has long been regarded as the best source of information for determining the sex of an unknown individual.
  • The femuris the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.
  • The sacrum is the least reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton - 100%
  • Pelvis alone - 95%
  • Skull alone - 92%
  • Pelvis plus skull - 98%
  • Long bones alone - 80%
  • Long bones plus pelvis - 98%
